abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory
            while project sustainability is rated highly likely. The
            performances of both the World Bank and the borrower are
            evaluated as satisfactory. The following lessons can be
            concluded from the project experience. 1) Project Design:
            The project design intentionally followed the lessons
            learned from prior education projects implemented in Latin
            America by keeping project components simple and
            well-defined. This approach was validated by the
            Borrower's sharp focus and ease of implementation of
            the components from the outset. The implementation
            experience generally yielded results that served to
            strengthen component design, achieve the development
            objectives, and output indicators. The flexibility within
            components and ability to make changes during execution
            (e.g. production of student multigrade guidebooks rather
            than activity cards; emphasis on eduction management
            information system development for institutional
            strengthening) that were agreeable to both the government
            and the Bank, was a central factor in maintaining project
            relevancy while supporting the evolving education strategy.
            2) Continuity of Project Management: caused the successful
            implementation of the project. 3) Commitment and Interest of
            High Level Ministry Officials: Top Ministry officials
            participated in policy decisions to facilitate
            implementation of the First Basic Education Project, as well
            as in the shaping of strategies for conceptualization and
            preparation of the new Second Basic Education Project. It is
            also important to have an administration willing to continue
            operations initiated by the former government, not just for
            continuity in improving education quality, equity and
            access, but also for building on improvements in the
            modernization and strengthening of the Ministry and
            implementing agency. 4) Targeting: Students in lower income
            families usually have no access to quality preschool
            education programs or to necessary school materials and
            texts. The project's emphasis on specifically targeting
            the poorest areas within Panama and refining the areas of
            poverty down to the neediest 185 corregimientos, enabled the
            project to impact areas where the need was highest. 5)
            Community Participation. The project's support of
            parent and community participation in physical maintenance
            of schools and in provision of non-formal preschool
            education services in rural and marginal urban areas has
            shown that community involvement in the operation of schools
            adds an important dimension to the effectiveness of publicly
            provided education by mobilizing local support for the
            schools and increasing pride in achievement on the part of
            students and teachers. 6) Gradual Expansion of Non-formal
            Preschool. Experience shows that instead of moving to a
            massive expansion of the project's less expensive,
            non-formal preschool model utilizing community
            participation, there is a need to consolidate
            institutionalization of the program at the central and
            regional levels, while building education ministry's
            institutional capacity to follow up and promote the program
            among dispersed rural populations that are difficult to
            reach. For this reason, a continued course of gradual
            expansion has been chosen, aiming to reach the children in
            remote rural localities and marginal urban communities first
            under the Second Basic Education Project.
